Reference Text: <S ssid="1" sid="24">Sentence pairs are the natural instances for SMT, but sentences often contain a mix of domain-specific and general language.</S><S ssid="1" sid="62">To approximate these baselines, we implemented a very simple sentence selection algorithm in which parallel sentence pairs from OUT are ranked by the perplexity of their target half according to the IN language model.</S><S ssid="1" sid="26">Phrase-level granularity distinguishes our work from previous work by Matsoukas et al (2009), who weight sentences according to sub-corpus and genre membership.</S><S ssid="1" sid="1">We describe a new approach to SMT adaptation that weights out-of-domain phrase pairs according to their relevance to the target domain, determined by both how similar to it they appear to be, and whether they belong to general language or not.</S>
